positive.review:
I've played a lot of city builders. I've managed resources, optimized production chains, and built sprawling metropolises. But Frostpunk isn't just a city builder - it's a MORAL RECKONING disguised as a survival game.

The premise is deceptively simple: the world has frozen over, and you're leading the last city on Earth around a massive coal-powered generator. Keep people warm. Keep them fed. Keep them alive. But here's where Frostpunk transcends the genre - it forces you to answer an impossible question: How far will you go to save your people?

Let me paint you a picture of what this actually feels like:

It's 3 AM. My city is dying. Half my population is sick, the other half is starving. The coal mines are almost empty, and the generator is sputtering. I have exactly ONE decision left to make, and both options are absolutely bad. I'm sweating despite the fact that my screen is showing -150¬∞C. I make the choice. Children go to work in the coal mines.

I feel PHYSICALLY ILL. The city survives another day :)

Every single decision feels like you're carving pieces out of your own humanity just to keep that beautiful, terrible generator running one more day. Will you establish a surveillance state to maintain order? Will you let the sick die to save resources? The game doesn't judge you - it just watches, coldly, as you make these choices and live with the consequences.

The atmosphere is unmatched. The Victorian steampunk aesthetic mixed with apocalyptic desperation is perfect. The visual design of watching your city huddle around that glowing generator while the temperature drops is both beautiful and terrifying. And the soundtrack? Good LORD, the soundtrack will haunt your dreams. It is devastating, swelling at exactly the moment you realize you've become the monster to save the man.

I've stared at my screen and laughed at the desperation of the situation. I've felt genuine pride when we survived against impossible odds. But even after finishing multiple scenarios, I still think about the choices I made.

Frostpunk isn't about winning. It's about surviving and discovering what kind of leader you become when hope itself starts to freeze. This game will challenge you, and make you question your own morality. And you'll love every painful second of it.

I'm not done with this one, not by a long shot, but I find myself for the first time properly interested in trying other games in the genre out. If that isn't high praise, I don't know what is.

Or building-specific events like: "the workers in the coal mine find an abandoned mineshaft, they can extract 3 steam-cores, but it takes 12 hours, and people might get hurt." or resource-specific events like: "we have a serious food shortage, a group of people want to wander out of the frozen wasteland to find food, would you allow them?" 

Also, in the endless mode, I would love to see multiple manageable cities.

The free scenarios were frustrating but the DLC scenarios were really good, I would like to see more of them.
Several scenarios with slightly different mechanics keep the game interesting and the balance is well done so nothing is exceptionally overpowered or underpowered.

I want to admit upfront that I‚Äôm not very good at the game yet, and that I only got this so that I would have story context for the second game, which I was actually more interested in, but regardless of these things, and regardless of the completionist that dies within me when I look at the achievements for this game, it is immensely fun. It is one of the most complete, most nerve-racking, most edge-of-your-seat type city builders I have ever played, and it fills my little sci-fi dystopian-loving heart with such chills for every additional word I read into the story of this world. It might take me a century to be good, and a millennium to complete everything, but that feeling of suspense through the coming storm and the overwhelming feeling of victory at the end of my 5th attempt at a scenario on easy mode still excites me enough to see my way through it. If you have time on your hands, the patience and anger management of a saint, and a love for worlds such as these, I highly, highly recommend.

Frostpunk ‚Äî Leadership, Sacrifice, and Survival in a Frozen World

Frostpunk thrusts players into a brutally cold, post-apocalyptic world where humanity‚Äôs last hope lies in a single city built around a massive generator. As the leader, you‚Äôll face impossible decisions, balancing survival, morality, and the needs of your people as temperatures plummet and resources vanish. From the first moment, the game establishes a grim yet compelling tone that rarely lets up.

The game shines in its city-building and survival mechanics. Every choice matters‚Äîwhere you place buildings, how you manage coal, food, and shelter, and how you prepare for the next deadly cold wave. The pressure never fades, and the sense of responsibility is constant. The laws you enact, whether compassionate or ruthless, shape both the city and its people in lasting ways.

Decision-making is the beating heart of Frostpunk. The moral dilemmas are powerful, often forcing you to choose between efficiency and humanity. Will you build hope, enforce order, or sacrifice ethics for survival? Each route offers unique challenges and emotional weight, making every playthrough feel personal and impactful.

Atmosphere and presentation are exceptional. The stark, snow-covered landscapes, detailed city animations, and haunting music create a chilling yet beautiful world. The visual storytelling‚Äîfading light, frostbitten buildings, and workers huddling for warmth‚Äîadds depth to the struggle of your citizens and the sacrifices they endure.

[h3]Final Verdict:[/h3]
Frostpunk is a masterful blend of strategy, survival, and moral storytelling. Challenging, emotional, and deeply immersive, it stands as one of the most compelling city-building experiences ever made. Whether you rule with compassion or cold logic, the journey will stay with you long after the generator‚Äôs heat fades.

Holy crap. It's difficult to make a game that creates so much tension that the player is at the edge of their seat, hyper-focused, fully engaged, invested, and locked-in. It's even more difficult to do that with the genres of city-building and survival, but, dang; 11 bit studios not only pulls it off but smashes it out of the park, delivering a truly intense gaming experience despite the genre.

Gameplay is immensely satisfying, challenging, and gratifying. Strategic placement of each individual structure is key to successfully maximizing your resources, which just affords a level of strategic depth to rival even the most tactical and strategic games. A wide array of difficulty settings and game modes makes the game surprisingly accessible even to more casual players, though the game was definitely intended for the more invested.

But where this game really shines is purely in the aesthetic, atmosphere, and story-telling, even though it is not particularly narrative-driven. I'm already a bit of a sucker for steampunk, but I'm also a sucker for the narrative feature of battling harsh and supernaturally overwhelming elements, and this marries the two perfectly. Furthermore, the technology and policy choices really lend themselves to the idea of abandoning moral norms in the name of survival.

Frostpunk is a survival city-building strategy game developed by 11 bit studios. It challenges players to manage the last city on Earth after a global freeze, balancing efficiency, morality, and survival. Every decision carries weight, forcing compromise between compassion and necessity.

Gameplay revolves around resource management and city planning. Players gather coal, wood, and steel to keep a central generator running‚Äîthe city‚Äôs only heat source. Expansion is constant tension: spreading too far wastes fuel, staying too close risks stagnation. Each day brings new hardships, from blizzards to food shortages.

The law and hope systems define the game‚Äôs moral complexity. Players enact laws that shape society‚Äîchild labor, food rationing, emergency shifts‚Äîeach carrying moral and psychological costs. The balance between order and hope determines the colony‚Äôs endurance more than any resource.

Visually, Frostpunk captures despair and resilience. The frozen wasteland contrasts sharply with the warm glow of the generator. Buildings radiate light against endless snow, giving the city a fragile beauty. The weather effects and lighting reinforce the sense of isolation and urgency.

Sound design deepens immersion. The creaking of ice, the hum of the generator, and the haunting orchestral soundtrack all sustain the tone of endurance against extinction. The audio reinforces every choice‚Äîthe quiet aftermath of death and the cold wind of survival.

The campaign delivers a contained but powerful narrative, with multiple scenarios expanding replay value. Each scenario redefines priorities‚Äîexploration, faith, or order‚Äîand tests different management styles. The difficulty remains high, but victory feels earned rather than scripted.

Overall, Frostpunk is a city builder about survival, sacrifice, and the limits of morality. It‚Äôs less about expansion and more about preservation. Beautiful, brutal, and unforgettable, it stands as one of the few strategy games that forces players to question not how they build‚Äîbut what they‚Äôre willing to do to keep the lights on.

Frostpunk ‚Äì Pros & Cons
Pros:
Story is strong and emotionally engaging.
Graphics are gorgeous and fit the bleak setting perfectly.
Music and sound design are excellent and enhance immersion.
The amount of detail is impressive (workers pushing snow, heat zones, etc.).
Weather system is dynamic and adds depth to the survival challenge.
UI is minimalistic but clear and functional.
The atmosphere makes the world genuinely feel cold.
Difficulty encourages thoughtful planning and tough decision-making.
The Law system allows interesting moral and social paths (even harsh ones).
Storytelling rewards paying attention instead of handing everything to the player.
Cons:
Can be unforgiving for new players.
Game length is short, with limited scenarios.
Lack of modding support reduces replayability.
Overall:
Frostpunk is a powerful and immersive city-survival experience with amazing atmosphere and meaningful choices. However, more game modes and mod support would make its longevity even better. It remains a standout title worth playing.

You‚Äôll need quick reactions here ‚Äî both for your dosa and your frostbitten workers.

I'm sick of games that are "Nearly impossible by default". I don't want to learn a game where there is basically only a SLIVER of possible ways to win, because any other method is brutally destroyed. What happened to Normal difficulty and I raise it to Hard when I feel like it? Further, the game is poorly designed around Knowledge Checkpoints. I'm on my 2nd round and at some point it's like "Oh by the way, in 7 days, you need 3000 food stored up". It gives you only a 7 day warning... but it is *impossible* to save up 3000 food in 7 days. I had *7* hunters huts. 105 workers. Still not enough. The ONLY way I could have saved that food in time is if I know about it in advance. That's just bad. Let's translate this to a different genre: FPS. In a GOOD FPS game I can be playing it BLIND and get ambushed, but using SKILL ALONE, I *should* be able to overcome that ambush, even if I have to reload the checkpoint at the beginning of the ambush a few times, the point is that the fight *in that moment* ***IS*** winnable. Now in a BAD FPS game, I would learn that the *only* way to win the ambush is that *before* the ambush I had to push some button on a wall somewhere. Which means no matter how many times I reload that blind checkpoint at the beginning of the ambush, I never even have a *chance* to win because I didn't know the Knowledge Checkpoint of the random button on the wall. That's what it is like to be given only 7 days notice to get 3000 food on your 2nd blind playthrough. That's ass. How many more save files will I have to trudge through to learn all the Knowledge Checkpoints before I'm allowed to win? How can we claim a Deep Victory over the game when the only way to win is to essentially cheat? Roleplaying wise does my town captain or whatever know what is coming? NO! Then why should *I* know what is coming either?! The only way a city survives is if their leader is in touch with the Heavens and knows shit in advance? That's such mind numbing garbage! Immersion RUINED!

If you like that level of challenge and all the mental gymnastics, then this is the game for you! Just not my cup of tea.

would love to play this game but everytime i turn it n, it chuggs to the point it crashes

I'm sick of games that are "Nearly impossible by default". I don't want to learn a game where there is basically only a SLIVER of possible ways to win, because any other method is brutally destroyed. What happened to Normal difficulty and I raise it to Hard when I feel like it? Further, the game is poorly designed around Knowledge Checkpoints. I'm on my 2nd round and at some point it's like "Oh by the way, in 7 days, you need 3000 food stored up". It gives you only a 7 day warning... but it is *impossible* to save up 3000 food in 7 days. I had *7* hunters huts. 105 workers. Still not enough. The ONLY way I could have saved that food in time is if I know about it in advance. That's just bad. Let's translate this to a different genre: FPS. In a GOOD FPS game I can be playing it BLIND and get ambushed, but using SKILL ALONE, I *should* be able to overcome that ambush, even if I have to reload the checkpoint at the beginning of the ambush a few times, the point is that the fight *in that moment* ***IS*** winnable. Now in a BAD FPS game, I would learn that the *only* way to win the ambush is that *before* the ambush I had to push some button on a wall somewhere. Which means no matter how many times I reload that blind checkpoint at the beginning of the ambush, I never even have a *chance* to win because I didn't know the Knowledge Checkpoint of the random button on the wall. That's what it is like to be given only 7 days notice to get 3000 food on your 2nd blind playthrough. That's ass. How many more save files will I have to trudge through to learn all the Knowledge Checkpoints before I'm allowed to win? How can we claim a Deep Victory over the game when the only way to win is to essentially cheat? Roleplaying wise does my town captain or whatever know what is coming? NO! Then why should *I* know what is coming either?! The only way a city survives is if their leader is in touch with the Heavens and knows shit in advance? That's such mind numbing garbage! Immersion RUINED!

But it is extremely punishing and with a very out-dated introduction/tutorial in comparison to what you actually need to know to make it work past the first challenge, you notice all the focus developing this game went into mechanics and design rather than player experience.

If you like pain, go ahead. If you want a normal chill but challenging city builder: hands off! This is a fckng hard game.

Buy on sale.
one update without any noticeable changes and your game from 3gb become 9gb.

I wanted to love Frostpunk but between some questionable execution, demanding mechanics+citizens, and a scheduled Disaster that the game doesn't warn you about but also has at the exact same time every time (why? it doesn't incentivize you to be prepared for disasters in general, just plan around specific scripted events, while still being painful for no real payoff). I don't think it's a terrible game - it's got things to love and you can see that people do love it - but it really isn't for me.

(What I wanted from Frostpunk, I eventually got from Against the Storm, which has a similar idea of colony+base building in a limited, hostile environment, but goes both broader with the mechanic and deeper by making it cyclical on several levels, meaning messing up doesn't mean a complete game over. I sometimes think about trying Frostpunk again, but nothing it has is more appealing to me than just about everything in AtS. Take that as you will.)

Could be an enjoyable game if it wasn't for dumb mechanics. Endless mode I find interesting but leaves much to be desired. Only buy this game if on sale, it's not worth $50+ with DLC's. Beat the primary scenario in under 10 hours of playtime.

Without using cheats, this is basically impossible to win in any scenario. The game is aesthetically pleasing, I loved Ixion, but unless you adhere to one very specific META guide to how to finish X scenario, you just get deposed, everyone dies, or everyone gets sick. This needed way more playtesting with average gamers.

And yes, it's a skill issue. But that skill issue shouldn't make the game less fun for the average player. At least have an actual easy mode that isn't "google how to use cheats"

I bought this game because it was super cheap on a sale but I couldn't get into it. I could not play for more than half an hour at a time without getting bored or stressed and whenever I went to play again I always felt like I had to restart because I felt like I hadn't done it right, in part because the game doesn't have a great tutorial and there is such a large element of trial and error that you always wonder if you did things optimally. Anyway this resulted in me never getting more than like 4 days in on any of my playthroughs and I have to desire to continue or start over because it's just like pure stress and no fun. I think the UI is part of what stressed me out but I don't know, all I know is that I regret the time I put into it. It's weird because I watched part of a youtube letsplay beforehand and it looked cool but I think that's because the guy playing was familiar with it so it didn't seem stressful.

While I appreciate what Frostpunk is trying to do, I didn‚Äôt find it very fun to actually play. The atmosphere is great, and I can see why people love the tension and moral weight of it all, but for me, it was just depressing. Every decision feels like a slow slide into misery, and instead of feeling challenged or clever, I mostly felt drained.

It takes all the unfun parts of crafting and survival, scarcity, micromanaging, constant loss, and builds an entire experience around them. I respect the vision, but I never felt any satisfaction or sense of payoff. Frostpunk is impressive, but not enjoyable.
I like the game but these villagers are too damn demanding. I'll rather kill everyone than letting them live and complain. Just get up and COLLECT RESOURCES FASTER, no teamwork and survival instincts
paying for a endless mode is one of the scummiest things i ever seen in a city-builder game
